original: Jagitsch, Robert Karl Ignaz, docent, Göteborg, f. 1/2/10 i Wien av Ignaz Johann J. o. Antonie Jagitsch. G. 37 m. Anni Gergely. Barn: Peter f. 41, Thomas 44. — Stud:ex. 28, Dr. phil. v. univ. i Wien 37. Stud:res. t. Holl. o. Tyskl. 29, Balkan 31, Ital. 33, Berlin (Kaiser Wilhelm Inst. f. Chemie) 34-35, Köpenhamn (femte nord. kemistmötet) 39, Schweiz, Österr., Tjec-koslov. o. Polen samt Norge 47. De-monstrator v. Chem. Univ:lab. i Wien 35-37, lab :chef v. Metallw^erk Undon AG i Wöllersdorf 37-38, doc. v. CTH sed. 43. Sv. medborg. 42. Led. av Tekn. samf. i Gbg 46. Skr.: Under-sökn. över radioaktiva indikatorers användn. f. utredn. av diffusion o. kem. omsättn. i fasta ämnen (i sv., österr. o. tyska tidskr. 35-42), über das Problem der Verv^itterung antiker Gläser (tills. m. J. A. Hedvall o. G. Olson 43 o. 47), Undersökn. över reaktion skin et ik^en i fasta faser (i sv., eng. o. schv^eiziska tidskr. fr. 42).
translated: Jagitsch, Robert Karl Ignaz, docent, Gothenburg, born February 1, 1910 in Vienna to Ignaz Johann J. and Antonie Jagitsch. Married in 1937 to Anni Gergely. Children: Peter, born in 1941, and Thomas, born in 1944. Completed secondary school in 1928 and earned a PhD from the University of Vienna in 1937. Went on study trips to Holland and Germany in 1929, the Balkans in 1931, Italy in 1933, Berlin (Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Chemistry) in 1934-35, Copenhagen (fifth Nordic Chemists Meeting) in 1939, Switzerland, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Norway in 1947. Worked as a demonstrator at the Chemical University Laboratory in Vienna from 1935-37, laboratory manager at Metallwerk Undon AG in Wöllersdorf from 1937-38, and docent at Chalmers University of Technology since 1943. Became a Swedish citizen in 1942 and became a member of the Technical Society in Gothenburg in 1946. Wrote: Investigations into the use of radioactive indicators for the study of diffusion and chemical reactions in solid materials (in Swedish, Austrian, and German journals from 1935-1942), On the problem of the opacification of ancient glasses (together with J.A. Hedvall and G. Olson in 1943 and 1947), and Investigations into the reaction kinetics of solid phases (in Swedish, English and Swiss journals, 1942 onwards).
